CCOLA and Mars. Nasa has released the first pictures taken by the Perseverance rover on Mars, including a selfie with his robotic arm for comparison. The images show Perseverance sitting at the base of a dune on the edge of the Jezero Crater. In a tweet, Nasa said they “show everything a geologist could want.” “We’re looking forward to seeing Perseverance dig up more Martian dirt to better understand if this ancient site ever held life,” the space agency wrote.
Freddie Mercury was HIV positive when he recorded the lead vocals for Killer Queen, it has been revealed. The band’s long-serving drummer, Roger Til, admitted Queen never discussed their lead singer’s condition. In a special 50th anniversary album, he spoke about a conversation in 1991 that shed new light on the legendary song. Freddie, who died in 1991, did not reveal to the band, his bandmates – Brian May, John Deacon and Dr Til – until his death. Freddie Mercury, who died in 1991, was diagnosed with HIV in 1987 and died of complications related to the disease. Killer Queen was released in 1974 as part of four-track album, titled Sheer Heart Attack. It will be published next month to mark the 50th anniversary of the band’s first performance. Read the full article to see how to buy the new anniversary album and read a rare interview with Roger.
The world’s shortest people have united across borders to form an unprecedented community organization, which will bring together the Tutsi (from Rwanda) and the Tikaro (from Burundi). It is being launched in Kigali, Rwanda’s capital, but the name is shrouded in secrecy. The organization’s president, identified only as Nyamahoro, hopes to “improve the lives of the smallest members of their families.” “We have people with very short statures who have suffered and who may continue to suffer,” the 40-year-old said by telephone. “Our main goal is to change the life of these people for the better.” As part of the new organization, 26-year-old Tikaro, an HIV patient, is looking for funding and better access to medication. “My name is Dizemihinda, but I love being called Tikaro, because I know that I am a king, and as the king I deserve to be treated well,” he said. “I feel good and I have the energy to do the things I love in life,” he added.
The body has been uncovered 30 years after a former Royal Marine’s remains were thrown into the sea by a submarine. The Defense Ministry announced on Wednesday that the corpse of Marine Cdr Edward Lillie, aged 36, whose remains were discovered in a watery grave off the coast of Greece after more than two years of legal battles, had been exhumed. A coroner ruled the coroner’s death was due to drowning after his submersible died on September 1, 1991. “Edward wanted to make a difference to other people,” said one of his brothers, Alan, a former Royal Welsh Fusilier. “He was a wonderful brother, husband, uncle, and in the days after his disappearance I was left wondering if the worst was over.” Mr. Lilly’s family also described him as “funny, sensitive and kind”.
Roger Mills was found hanged by his mother in July 2020
A young man whose death at the hands of his estranged mother at a house in the Wirral was tragic, inquests found. Detectives and mental health service staff said 23-year-old Roger Mills had “significant mental health issues” before his death in July 2020. An inquest ruled that the death was a suicide. Roger, from Shotton, was under pressure to find a new flat to rent and he suffered from depression, his father Peter Mills told the court. The inquest heard that he had been involved with drug addiction and on October 19, his mother Gillian Mills had arranged to take him to a hotel where he would be given clean clothes and a place to stay overnight. However, he did not arrive home and the following day he sent an unknown number to his father to say he would be home this afternoon. On October 22, Gillian Mills was dead at home after being found hanged. Roger’s family appealed the decision and said it was a “complete shock”.

Sixteen-year-old Mar Winnick spends her days in her bedroom — writing stories and eavesdropping on what's going on in the outside world. Mar has no intention of moving on. She understands and admires the world better through her stories and her imagination. Her family tries to make her join everything and live in the real world, but she's having none of it. As for her friends at school, they've found some common ground and try to make Mar a part of their lives, but she's no more interested in moving on. She has no trouble making friends, but she's not at all interested in forming real connections. Mar's mind lives and shines within the worlds she creates in her stories, and she wants it to stay that way.
While writing her fiction, which is full of the rich details and complex, engaging characters that have made Tove Jansson one of the most celebrated writers of our time, Tove Jansson herself struggled to maintain the balance between these two realities of her life. She also struggled to find the right balance between the needs of art and those of everyday life, to satisfy one's artistic and personal needs despite the limitations imposed by living in Stockholm. When she lost her mother at age eleven, her father tried to teach her by giving her drawing lessons — he was a painter and a very strict and demanding teacher, but Tove was better at drawing than any of her classmates. But as an adult and in a way in spite of the encouragement she received from her father, Tove Jansson found it difficult to paint. She made many attempts to find her way as an artist, but it wasn't until 1958, when she was forty years old, that the artist's identity she had nurtured throughout her life manifested itself in the first comic strips drawn by Tove Jansson. The beginning her cartoon series (which lasted until 2001) was followed by other series, as well as a number of short stories and illustrations for many collections. She had already begun writing short stories: she had published her first book, Sara and Karl, in 1956 and by the time she was fifty she had written ten novels. Tove Jansson loved to play with different forms, moving back and forth between the stories and novels she wrote and the plays and comic strips. She never chose a preferred form and was always open to trying out new ways of expression. Her imagination knew no bounds and her stories reflected her endless fascination with the wonders and curiosities of life. She wrote and illustrated for newspapers and magazines, making short stories, satirical pieces, and many children's stories for Nordisk nyländare and Humör. She was a prolific illustrator and worked for newspapers in Sweden, Finland, Norway, and Denmark. This is how Tove Jansson expressed her views in an article she wrote for the newspaper Expressen: "An artist draws, paints, or writes — however you call it — so that other people can see what he or she has seen and also have that same feeling."
Through her fiction, Tove Jansson has opened the world of adults to countless children and brought the world of children to thousands of adults. She wanted her books to help bring the child in adults back, to remind them to be a little child as well as an adult, to feel the same wonder and amazement about the world that children do. With that goal in mind, it's no wonder she wrote stories and novels for children. She wrote the book she wanted to read when she was a child, but which she couldn't find. That book, the Moomin books, is without a doubt her greatest achievement and still her most beloved legacy. A series of stories that have been delighting and inspiring children and adults alike ever since their first publication, and will continue to do so throughout the 21st century.
In 1953, as she began the first children's book she had ever written, The moomins and the grey mouse, Tove Jansson was in her mid-thirties and had established herself as a painter and illustrator. She was an artist who lived and worked on the mainland (Stockholm), but one who felt she was completely at home on the Åland Islands (to which she had always been drawn). She had already published two books of short stories for adults in 1946 (Small Mercies) and in 1956 (Sara and Karl). At the time, both men and women were drawn towards these sorts of stories of the sea, islands, and landscapes of the Åland Islands. The islands were a source of inspiration for Tove Jansson, and on her many trips there, she would spend much more time alone there than she did with the rest of the island population. This probably goes to demonstrate one reason why Tove Jansson's first foray into authorship would be set on the strange island that is Moominvalley, home to the moomins, Snuxie the polar bear, and the groke, and which would become the backdrop for the rest of her books.
By 1957, when Tove Jansson finished The moomins and the great flood, she was already one of the most famous and respected artists in the country. She was living in Helsinki with her boyfriend, Tuulikki Pietilä, a landscape painter who was also a frequent inspiration, but it wasn't until 1957 that a book by Tove Jansson became a bestseller and one of the most well-known books of all time.
The Moomin series of books have been translated into more than fifty languages and have been printed in 14 million copies: they are true bestsellers. Although she was the author of some of the most enduring classics ever, Tove Jansson never believed that it was possible to create literature that lasted for all time; instead, she believed that it is literature that has already passed its peak that survives longest. She did not want to be remembered, but would rather be remembered for her art and illustrations.
Tove Jansson was awarded the Nordic Council's Literature Prize in 1966 for The Summer Book  and the International Hans Christian Andersen Honorary Diploma in 1998. In addition, she received the first Tucholsky Prize (1982) and the Pro Finlandia Medal (1990). Many of Tove Jansson's awards and recognitions were published in the Svenska Dagbladet in May 1999, celebrating both her birth centenary that year and her contribution to culture. In 1999, she established the Tove Jansson Foundation. In 2003, she donated the remaining works in her personal collection (paintings, prints, sketches, and furnishings) to the museums of Finland. These collections are now housed in Stockholm and Helsinki. She also left instructions with her heirs to make sure her books are to be distributed for a period of fifty years.
Tove Jansson passed away in 2001. In 2013, she was remembered in a number of literary events organized by the Finnish institute in Stockholm where she was also honored with an annual award for literary prizes. The Tove Jansson Award is given to outstanding Scandinavian literature.
Although Jansson has an extensive body of work, her most famous book is the Moomin series. The Moomins has seen over 150 million hardcover copies sold globally and has been translated into more than 40 languages.
The Moomins were created by Tove Jansson in the late 1940s while in the company of her boyfriend, Anders Tengelin.
In 2012, The Moomin Books was adapted into a theatre production by Toby Peet of London and has been played several times since.
Tove Jansson has seen interest in her work resurge with the release of The Pirate Grandpa by the publishing company Eden Studios.
What Was Tove Jansson's Profession?
Jansson was a Swedish artist and a renown children’s books writer, well known for writing the character of the Moomins. She was also a comic strip writer and illustrator.

What Is Tove Jansson Famous For?
When writing her Moomin books, Jansson found solace and inspiration in Moomin Valley. She felt that her love of Moomin Valley came from its isolation that made it a place that was uncontaminated by the world outside.
Tove also wrote a book about her struggle with depression and her struggles with her mental health.

This essay has been requested for highschool English test. Since many people asked for one, I have written an essay on the grammar of "r" and "n".
The grammar of "r" and "n" is one of the most often confused grammatical concepts people have. The reason for this is easy to explain, because most people who have never studied grammar before have no clue how to use the "r" or "n" and therefore misuse the two words.
In order to understand the proper usage of the "n", simply put the letter "n" as a placeholder in place of a letter "r". The reason why the "r" does not have to be mentioned in the sentence is because the "n" is not a letter. When someone says an "n", it is a part of the sentence that is not being pronounced and therefore does not need to be mentioned in the sentence.
The best example I can give to show how this works would be a sentence like "The boy was not at school today." The sentence is saying that the boy went to school and did not go to school today, but he went to school and came home to be with his family today. Therefore, the "n" is not being pronounced in this sentence and is being used to indicate that the "n" is the proper word to use in the sentence.
In the sentence "The boy was at school today," the "n" is simply saying that the boy went to school and came home to be with his family today. There is no reason for anyone to say an "n" when they are at home. They can just leave it out of the sentence, because it is not being used to indicate anything.
Another way of saying the word "n" in this sentence is "he does not care to get up for school, but I can always get him to go to school." This sentence can be confusing to people who have never studied grammar before because both phrases are using two different things.
The "n" is used to make a word plural, which is a very common grammatical term. It means to make a word into two separate words. This might sound confusing to some people, but the two separate words are being used interchangeably.
In another sentence I might say, "This is my car." The word "car" is being used as a noun to indicate what kind of car this person is talking about.
This is a very difficult concept for most people to understand. The concept of making a word into two separate words is not something that is taught to many people before they start to study grammar.
But once a person learns that the two different words are being used interchangeably, they will know that the "r" is the right word to use. and that when they are referring to something as a noun that they are referring to a noun. The key to knowing that you are talking about a noun and not a word is to use the "r". and not the "n".
Another example of this is "the boy was at school today". and the sentence "The boy was at school today, but not at school today." is saying that the boy was actually at school even though he went to school today.
One more example of this would be to say "The boy is at school today" and "The boy was at school." is saying that the boy was at school but he actually went to school today.
In this example, the "r" is still being used to make the word "this" plural and therefore the "n" still has to be used. and not the "r" (in this example).

Grand Opening:
Mitochondria and chloroplasts have their own sets of genes, which means their genes do not have to depend on the nuclear genome for RNA requirements.
Each of the three membrane-enclosed regions of a cell is formed by the endoplasmic reticulum, the mitochondria, and the chloroplasts. These membrane-enclosed structures are all considered organelles, and are important to the survival of multicellular organisms. These organelles are created from a parental body called the rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER). The RER then differentiates into three daughter organelles, mitochondria, chloroplasts, and Golgi apparatus (Golgi). These daughter organelles undergo continued division and change in identity.
The Mitochondria and chloroplasts undergo cell division and can replicate genetic information. The mitochondria of a human is descended from the mitochondria of a bacteria, making these structures independent from the nucleus of the cell. These organelles can be identified by studying the nucleotide sequences inside each organelle. A close look at DNA from these organelles shows that they are circular and have small loops, unlike the linear DNA that is found in prokaryotes and in the nucleus of organisms. The DNA of chloroplasts shows signs that these structures are derived from free-living cyanobacteria. In spite of its difference from nuclear DNA, mitochondrial DNA has been found to have the ability to replicate and can sometimes be seen in prokaryotic cells, such as the bacteria mycoplasma, which are lacking nuclei.
The membranes of mitochondria (inner, outer membranes) and outer membranes of chloroplasts form a double layer of lipid bilayers. The DNA of both chloroplasts and mitochondria is in a circular double stranded form. There are both DNA strands in each organelle. Also, the genes within both these structures are similar in number and make-up. Mitochondria, as a structure, is found in both eukaryotic and prokaryotic organisms. However, only eukaryotic organisms possess chloroplasts. Plants are unable to have mitochondria and chloroplasts because they use chemosynthesis (or sunlight) to produce food from CO2 and water.
A cytoplasmic membrane structure known as ER (endoplasmic reticulum) exists prior to the formation of all three organelles, that is, mitochondria, chloroplasts, and Golgi apparatus. An ER-like membrane matrix forms the nucleus at the earliest points in the evolution history of living cells. Also, the RBC nucleus is a membrane structure that gives rise to mitochondria.
The mitochondrion and the chloroplasts are both double membrane-enclosed, circular, doubled-stranded, spiral DNA structures.
The mitochondrion's two membranes are connected to each other by a complex, interconnecting channel known as the cristae. They are divided into small, tubular segments, called cristae (singular = crista). Nested within the inner membrane are many cristae, which are further folded to enhance the efficiency of the electron transport chain. Some models picture the mitochondria as a torus; others liken their shape to that of a donut. In contrast to these views, the chloroplast appears to be more similar to elongated cylindrical shape. In either case, each organelle resembles a capsule.

The SER can generate energy in different ways. When the cells do not divide SER can generate energy by being part of the complex glycolysis, but when a cell is dividing SER generates energy in the citric acid cycle.

Blockchain technology has the potential to improve patient outcomes in several ways. First, blockchains can be used to store and share medical records. This can help ensure that providers have access to the most up-to-date information about a patient’s health history. Second, blockchains can be used to create trustless networks through which providers can exchange data and resources. This can help improve communication between providers, which can in turn lead to better patient care.
There are a number of potential applications of blockchain technology in the healthcare industry, including electronic patient records, supply chains, and prescription drug safety.
Electronic patient records:
Electronic patient records are vital to any healthcare system, and blockchains offer a secure and decentralized way to store them. Blockchains can help to eliminate the need for middlemen in the healthcare industry, and could make it easier for patients to track their own medical history. However, there are some potential security risks to consider before adopting blockchain technology in this area.
Supply chains:
Supply chains are an essential part of any healthcare system, and they too would benefit from a more efficient and transparent system. Blockchain technology could help to eliminate many of the problems currently inherent in supply chains, such as fraud. By creating a decentralized and secure system, blockchains would allow for better tracking of supplies from manufacturers to final users. This would help to ensure that all parties involved in the supply chain were properly compensated, and that each product reached its final destination.
Prescription drug safety:
Prescription drug safety has been an ongoing concern for years, as drugs have been found to be contaminated or mislabeled. Blockchain technology could help to solve this problem by creating a secure and transparent database of all prescription drugs. This would allow regulators and consumers to easily see which drugs are safe to use and which ones are not. In the event of a recall or shortage, blockchains could be used to track which drugs were distributed where, so that affected patients could be easily contacted.

-Medical supply chains. Blockchain could be used to track medical supplies from the time they are produced to the time they are delivered to a patient. This could help to reduce the risk of counterfeit drugs or other medical products and improve the quality of care.
-Patient data analysis. Blockchain could be used to store patient data in a decentralized manner, which would make it easier to analyze data on a large scale and spot trends that could lead to improved care.

There is a lot of talk about how blockchain technology can be used in the healthcare industry to improve care and reduce costs. But what are some of the specific applications that blockchain technology could have in the healthcare industry? In this section, we explore 5 potential applications of blockchain technology in healthcare: patient data security, medical records, patient-centric healthcare, supply chain management, and clinical trials.
Blockchain technology has the potential to improve patient data security and privacy. By using blockchain to store healthcare data, providers can ensure that the data is only accessible to authorized parties and cannot be compromised.
Blockchain technology also has the potential to improve medical records. By using blockchain to store medical records, providers can ensure that the records are accurate, up-to-date, and easily accessible.
Blockchain technology has the potential to improve patient-centric healthcare. By using blockchain to store patient health data, providers can ensure that patients have complete control over their data and can make informed decisions about their care.
Blockchain technology also has the potential to improve supply chain management. By using blockchain to track medical supplies, providers can ensure that the supplies are not counterfeit or contaminated and are available when needed.
Blockchain technology could also be used to improve clinical trials by ensuring that all data is accurate and timely and that no one individual has an unfair advantage over others in the trial.
